04_inferential_statistics/02_confidence_intervals/10_n_from_ME_prop_v3

We can approximate a 95% confidence interval of a proportion (where the 95% refers to how frequently these intervals straddle the population proportion) by using \(\hat{p} \pm \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}\). \[\text{lower boundary} = \hat{p} - \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}\] \[\text{upper boundary} = \hat{p} + \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}\] where \(\hat{p}\) is the sample proportion and \(n\) is the sample size. The 2 comes from the fact that 95% of normal measurements land within 2 standard deviations from the mean.

The quantity that we subtract from or add to the sample proportion is called the margin of error. \[\text{margin of error} = \frac{2 \sqrt{\hat{p}(1-\hat{p})}}{\sqrt{n}}\]

If we know \(\hat{p}\) will be approximately 0.18, and we want the margin of error to be approximately 0.011, then how large does the sample size need to be?

You can round your answer to two significant digits.
